At present, the majority of Group III U.S. air carriers are showing moderate recovery insofar as their stock is concerned.1 If the markets can be relied on as demonstrative of company health I think it unlikely that we will see any Group III carrier filing for bankruptcy by the end of November. If any of these carriers were going to file for bankruptcy in the considered period it was far more likely to have occurred in the May – July period as COVID was at it is “peak” travel season in the United States.2 While this was undoubtedly a gut punch to the airline industry if they were able to weather this storm it is likely that with the holiday travel season fast approaching and COVID travel restrictions easing in many areas of the nation, airlines will continue to see a progressive increase in business going forward.

Several air carriers have had to restructure or cease operations, but they are Group I and II U.S air carriers. https://www.bts.gov/topics/airlines-and-airports/number-332-%E2%80%93-air-carrier-groupings-2020

Back in May of 2020, President Trump signed a $58 billion bailout for airlines in the United States, expecting major airlines to be hit hard by COVID-19 (Business Insider, 2020). Initially, the virus prevented commercial air travel, but has since resumed with proper mitigation techniques and penalties for those passengers and airlines that are not following the proper protocols. Historic data suggests that none of the Group III air carriers were in danger of bankruptcy before COVID made an impact. Similar to the automobile industry bailouts in 2008, massive government bailouts allocated resources to saving airlines effected by COVID (CNBC, 2020). Lastly, major airline United Airlines already accepted large amounts of debt to prevent filing for bankruptcy, with hopes of an increased revenue stream as restrictions are lifted (Aviation Pros, 2020). With massive government support and allocated funding, my prediction is as follows: -5% Yes https://www.aviationpros.com/home/news/10406114/united-airlines-signs-off-on-3-billion-in-bankruptcy-exit-financing https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/08/over-40-airlines-have-failed-in-2020-so-far-and-more-are-set-to-come.html https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-airlines-that-failed-bankrupt-covid19-pandemic-2020-3

According to OAG, the world's leading provider of digital flight information, intelligence and analytics for airports, airlines and travel tech companies, the table below shows the change in the number of global flights and flights departing from various countries since January 2020 vs the same period in the previous year. The data has been extracted for each week this year, starting on Monday 6th January. Data for January through to July is the cumulative data for the weeks starting in each of those months, while August flights are displayed as the weekly variance with the same week in 2019. According to Madhu Unnikrishnan of Skift, “Travel recovery may be starting, but it may not be enough to save thousands of U.S. airline jobs. Unless Congress acts to extend payroll protections, mass layoffs could start on October 1. Bankruptcy isn’t likely this time around, as airlines still have access to capital, as a flurry of recent stock, bond, and asset sale transactions clearly show. No U.S. airline is anywhere close to running low on cash”.

Between 15 May 2020 and 30 November 2020, will any Group III U.S. carrier file for bankruptcy? Once again, Covid-19 is a major contributing factor to the survival of group III carriers. Travel has taken a dramatic hit because of the pandemic, “on Wednesday, Transportation Security Administration officers screened just shy of 95,000 people at airport checkpoints, a dramatic drop from the 2.3 million who passed through on the equivalent day in 2019” (Wallace, 2020). Airlines are losing money at a rapid rate and are having very little attendance, “even as Delta and the other major airlines in the United States dramatically slash schedules, they are averaging an anemic 23 passengers on each domestic flight and losing $350 million to $400 million a day as expenses like payroll, rent and aircraft maintenance far exceed the money they are brining in” (Chokshi, 2020). Even though airlines are losing money at a consistent rate, group III carries have survived. Airlines have been able to survive by taking on debt, “$67 billion of the new debt is composed f government loans ($50 billion), deferred taxes ($5 billion) and loan guarantees ($12 billion)” (Garcia, 2020). Another way airlines have been able to survive is through furloughs, “United Airlines and American Airlines have sent furlough notices to a total of more than 32,000 employees, saying they can’t afford to have them on payroll after Thursday-the expiration date for the federal CARES Act Payroll Support Program” (NPR,2020). Like all industries, air travel has been greatly affected. However, not every airline will furlough their employees, “‘Southwest has no current plans for furloughs,’ a company representative tells NPR, citing cost-cutting and voluntary agreements with workers. Delta is in a similar position” (NPR, 2020). The airline industry is grim. However, it is my belief that group III U.S. carriers will do everything in their power to avoid declaring bankruptcy. While Virgin has already declared bankruptcy, I do not believe anyone else will. Between government loans, restructuring, and pay cuts, airlines will be able to survive until the end of November, 2020. Wallace, G (2020, April 09). Airlines and TSA report 96% drop in air travel as pandemic continues. CNN Politics. Retrieved from: https://www.cnn.com/2020/04/09/politics/airline-passengers-decline/index.html Chokshi, N (2020, May 10). The Airline Business Is Terrible. It Will Probably Get Even Worse. The New York Times. Retrieved from: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/10/business/airlines-coronavirus-bleak-future.html NPR. (2020, October 01). United and American Airlines Tell 32,000 Employees They’re Now On Furlough. NPR. Retrieved from:https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/10/01/919029571/united-and-american-airlines-tell-32-000-employees-theyre-now-on-furlough

With domestic and international travel severely impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, the 18 Group III US air carriers have been forced to adapt (Josephs, 2020). To be classified as a Group III air carrier, companies must have operating revenue boundaries of over $1 billion (Chadwick, 2019). Airlines are currently transitioning to cater to leisure travelers as business travel largely halted in midst of the pandemic and damaged economy with an observed 58% decrease in travel observed in April 2020 compared to 2019 (Josephs, 2020; Nguyen & Animashaun, 2020). The air industry received a $25 billion bailout in mid-April to keep them afloat through September (Rappeport & Chokshi, 2020). However, with no second bailout currently reached, airlines have begun to shrink through employee layoffs and groundings of aircraft to remain afloat (Egan, 2020). With talks about a second economic relief bill at a standstill, the airlines are expected to continue to shrink up to 50% and continue to reduce prices and erroneous fees to entice travelers to purchase tickets (Egan, 2020; Josephs, 2020). According to Oscar Munoz former CEO of United Airlines, while the situation is dire and numerous airlines have filed for bankruptcy in the previous two decades following 9/11 and the recession, with layoffs and fleet reductions major carriers likely to survive through the year (Egan, 2020). While additional bailouts may not be reached prior to or even immediately after the election on 3 November, layoffs, fleet reductions, minor increases in leisure travel observed due to incentives, and roughly one and a half months left, I estimate there is a 10% probability that a Group III US air carrier will declare bankruptcy by 30 November. https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/28/coronavirus-air-travel-focus-on-leisure-travelers.html

Group III U.S. air carriers are the top air carriers with operating revenues of over $1 billion. (Chadwick, 2020). These air carriers have been kept afloat by the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES Act), which extended payroll support to businesses and was signed into law on 27 March 2020. (Department of the Treasury, 2020). Unfortunately, the CARES Act expired on 30 September. This triggered layoffs at American Airlines and United Airlines, with Southwest Airlines warning layoffs could be coming soon (Ackley, 2020).

Despite all of the money that has been handed out throughout the COVID-19 pandemic airlines have been reducing the amount of flights that they are running. For publicly traded companies we can use the butterfly prices to imply an underlying distribution for the stock price up until Nov 30. From this, we can derive the probability of bankruptcy (the low end of the strike prices). For non publicly traded companies we assume they have several factors that would indicate if they are more or less likely to go bankrupt but have no strong conviction in this assumption and default to what will be our new implied base rate.

As my colleagues have pointed out, implied default probabilities from CDS give an approximate of ~10%. While correlations shift this higher, more prevalent in my mind is that bailouts and the possibility of acquisitions or other workarounds (default does not imply bankruptcy filing) shift the probability of bankruptcy down.

Updating the default risks implied by CDS, we have 14.62% and 19.04% for our raw values based on independence and a 0.3 or 0.4 proportion of 1-year CDS in the next 1.5 months. Given we only have 1.5 months, I'm more inclined to use the 0.3 proportion and assign a small correlation premium to 19%.

Part of the reason my forecast reflects this is by just paying attention to travel activity in the US, as indicated by TSA throughput (https://www.tsa.gov/coronavirus/passenger-throughput), there has been a recent uptick in the amount of travel, cracking 900,000 for the first time this week.
Initial forecast based on team & crowd consensus

Using historical bankruptcies of group III carriers since 2002, got a base rate of 0.61 bankruptcies per year. Then used a poisson dist (seems like an okay model choice) to estimate that there is a .46 chance of nonzero bankruptcies in any year. Given that we're only estimating until nov 30 and 2/3 of the year has passed, I should lower this probability. Then, given all covid news, I should increase the prob. Don't have a great way to do these bayesian updates but I'll say net effect is lowering probability from 0.46

Baseline: Very similar to my colleagues, the most reliable way to predict the default probability for the carriers is looking at the default probabilities in the market (near-term CDS). Therefore, we arrive at our baseline as follows: P(no default) = (1 - P(Alaska default)) * (1 - P(Allegiant default)) * ... * (1 - P(UPS default)). This gives us a probability of ~8%.
I was on the wrong side of this, apparently.
Base rate: As a base rate I use the risk-neutral implied probabilities of default from the near term CDS. This gives me a proxy of 10%. This looks very low compared to the crowd estimated to 50%.

Similar to @dzhou3 I looked at the 3 month implied default probability on bloomberg. For private companies I looked at whether they wer passenger or cargo airlines (as the effect of covid varies greatly between these subgroups) and took the group mean for each and then biased default risk up slightly due to the smaller size of the privately held companies which in increases default risk. This gave me a result somewhat lower than his 10%, I also think that the effect of correlations is overestimated, by making a small upward adjustment, I arrived at a 10% likelihood for a credit default.

This question is quite difficult to forecast, especially seeing there doesn't seem to be much news relating to airlines bankruptcy over the past few months. One very important thing to recognize is that Congress approved a $50B bailout ($25B in loans, $25B in grants) to the airline industry earlier this year, which is massive considering that marketcaps of the largest airline companies (excluding UPS) now are around ~20B. It's also important to recognize that many of the 18 airlines listed have significantly smaller market caps <$5B, thus the total bailout is quite substantial for the airline industry.
Slashing hard. Have been aggressively high for the entire duration...gonna start to bring that weighted average down...

I used the implied 3 month default probability from Bloomberg (this is the closest tenor to the prediction range). For companies that were owned by a holding company, I used that holding company's default probability. For Kalitta, this company seemed to be privately held so I estimated a 0.58% probability based on the average of the other companies. Therefore P(at least one defaults) = 1 - P(none default) = 1 - P(Alaska doesn't default) P(Allegiant doesn't default) ... (this is assuming independence which we will address) = 0.10. Now there is obviously an argument that these default probabilities do not fully capture pairwise correlation between defaults due to the structure of the market. I think this is difficult to value since it is not abundantly clear to me that if one of these companies defaulted, that the US government would allow another air carrier company to default (similar to 08 bailout of auto names). Nonetheless, I will assign a 10% correlation premium, bringing the probability to 20%.

Implied market from CDS is just under 20% if assuming that 40% of the 1 year implied default rate is contained in the next three months. However, this assumes no correlation, and while I'm not assuming perfect correlation, I think there would be pairwise correlation closer to 0.3. Since it is difficult to model joint distributions across 18 variables with only pairwise correlations, I'll assign a rough 50% premium to the default rate, giving me something slightly under 30%. I'll also adjust this slightly given the crowd consensus, but I am more inclined to believe the CDS markets.

Working on some math to see if my intuition is correct that it is better to *over wager* early on sudden death type questions like this. Seems like the way to check is calculate your Expected Brier Score, meaning, what your Brier Score would be on average for a question assuming you are handicapping it perfectly. For instance, say you think Event A has a uniform chance of happening over the course of 12 months of 80%. You could wager 80% at the start, reducing as time expires at an average rate of 20% (or 25% of your wager) per quarter. But my guess is a linearly sloped reduction isn't optimal for this reason: if Event A happens, it could happen at any time. OTOH, if it doesn't happen, it doesn't happen at the end of 12 months every time, meaning the average of all your forecasts are counted when the event doesn't happen, whereas when it does happen only your forecasts to-date are scored. So you want forecasts-to-date as high as possible when the event occurs and as low as possible when not. Morever, this gives the *early* forecasts much more weight than *late* forecasts when the event does occur because the early forecasts exist in more universes than the late forecasts, so to speak.

One should not forget: travel in general and tourism in particular got us into the dire straits we're now in in the first place - so why exactly should the taxpayer bail out each and every single factor for this pandemic? It is highly likely that the necessary capacity adjustments will not take place within every airline, but finally and more easily will happen by some of them going bust. The individual financing structure, major shareholders and exact conditions of leasing contracts and plane orders will determine at what time large lump sums and corporate actions will come due, and which of the carriers will have to file first. This, in turn, will leave some more headroom for the rest of the mob to survive. Even with a large portion of optimism and options like floating convertible bonds (e.g. CoCos), finding strategic investors, mergers etc etc, a bankruptcy seems inevitable. Furthermore, filing for bankruptcy has the charming effect of lowering (or getting rid of, altogether) the burden of costly and long standing pension schemes.
